Ganzouri]] |after_election = |before_party = Independent |after_party = }} {{Politics of Egypt}} An early '''parliamentary election''' is currently being held in [[Egypt]] from November 2011 onwards,{{cite web|url=http://www.monstersandcritics.com/news/middleeast/news/article_1629149.php/Egypt-to-hold-parliamentary-elections-in-September |title=Egypt to hold parliamentary elections in September |publisher=Monsters and Critics |date=28 March 2011 |accessdate=7 September 2011}} following the [[2011 Egyptian revolution|revolution which ousted]] President [[Hosni Mubarak]], after which the [[Supreme Council of the Armed Forces]] dissolved the [[parliament of Egypt]]. Originally, the election was assumed to be held in September, but this was postponed following protests that the early elections would benefit established parties.[http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-07-13/egypt-postpones-elections-purges-police-following-protests.html Egypt Postpones Elections, Purges Police Following Protests] Bloomberg, 13 July 2011 ==Background== In [[Egyptian parliamentary election, 2010|late 2010]], during the days of [[Husni Mubarak]], a parliamentary election was held, though it was followed by controversy and repression as well as accusations of fraud.[http://www.chron.com/disp/story.mpl/ap/top/all/7425408.html ]{{dead link|date=September 2011}} Following similar events in [[2010â2011 Tunisian revolution|Tunisia]] during the [[Arab Spring]], Egyptian activists called for protesters to turn up in cities around Egypt on various specially-designated days of rages. Though violence was reported at some points, protests were largely peaceful with the [[Egyptian Armed Forces|army]] staying quiet until 10 February 2011, when calls for Mubarak to resign were at their peak. The following day, Vice President [[Omar Suleiman]] announced Mubarak's resignation from the presidency while turning power over to the military. The Supreme Council of the Armed Forces, headed by Field Marshal [[Mohamed Hussein Tantawi]] would lead the country for a transitional period until a civilian government takes over. A [[Egyptian constitutional referendum, 2011|constitutional referendum]] was then approved on 19 March that would ease the process of electing a president.{{Citation needed|date=July 2011}} ==New electoral law== There were previously concerns that a change to the electoral system would be required, as the exsiting system mostly relyed on a district-based [[First-past-the-post voting]] system (designated for Individual candidates, as opposed to parties or coalition-lists) that was to favour the [[National Democratic Party (Egypt)|National Democratic Party]]{{cite web|url=http://www.carnegieendowment.org/publications/index.cfm?fa=view&id=42817 |title=Egyptâs Draft Constitutional Amendments Answer Some Questions and Raise Others - Carnegie Endowment for International Peace |publisher=Carnegieendowment.org |date= |accessdate=7 September 2011}}, The party of Mubarak loyalists. The National Democratic Party was however dissolved in April. The proposed draft law for the electoral system to be used was revealed on 30 May 2011; controversially, it retained first-past-the-post voting for two thirds of the seats, with only one third of the seats elected by [[proportional representation]].{{cite web|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/~/NewsContent/1/64/13291/Egypt/Politics-/Draft-law-draw-introducing-mixed-electoral-system-.aspx |title=Draft law introducing mixed electoral system triggers intense debate - Politics - Egypt - Ahram Online |publisher=English.ahram.org.eg |date=30 May 2011 |accessdate=7 September 2011}} However it was changed lates and 332 of MPs are going to be elected proportionally from lists. On 7 July 2011, the caretaker government approved the new electoral law. It outlined a new 50â50 division between proportional seats and FPTP seats; the minimum age limit for candidates is also to be reduced from 30 to 25.{{cite web|author=F_474 |url=http://english.people.com.cn/90001/90777/90855/7432343.html |title=Egypt's caretaker government passes draft law on parliamentary vote - People's Daily Online |publisher=English.people.com.cn |date=7 July 2011 |accessdate=7 September 2011}} On 21 July 2011, the SCAF announced:{{cite web|author=F_161 |url=http://english.people.com.cn/90001/90777/90854/7447621.html |title=Egypt to hold parliamentary elections in three rounds - People's Daily Online |publisher=English.people.com.cn |date=21 July 2011 |accessdate=7 September 2011}} * that the election (for both the People's Assembly and the Shura Council) would be held in three rounds in October, with 15-day intervals in-between; * that half the seats would be reserved for laborers and farmers; * that the women's quota introduced under Mubarak would be abolished. In late September 2011, again new division was announced, in which only one third of the seats would be elected by an FPTP vote.{{cite news| url=http://af.reuters.com/article/topNews/idAFJOE78N09Q20110924?pageNumber=1&virtualBrandChannel= | work=Reuters | title=Egypt changes election system in favour of party lists | date=24 September 2011}} However, these directly elected MPs could only be independents and not members of political parties; this restriction led to threats of boycotting the election by a wide swath of the political parties which intended to contest the election. The parties stated that their demands for a change in the electoral law would have to be met by 2 October, else they would boycott the election.{{cite news| url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-15101798 | work=BBC News | title=Egypt parties threaten boycott over election law | date=29 September 2011}}http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/09/2011928234830274426.html After a meeting with political party leaders on 1 October 2011, the SCAF agreed to allow party members to run for the directly elected seats, set a clearer timetable for the transition to civilian rule and possibly abolish military trials for civilians.http://www.dawn.com/2011/10/01/egypt-military-rulers-agree-to-amend-election-law.htmlhttp://www.dailystar.com.lb/News/Middle-East/2011/Oct-02/150251-egypt-parties-to-review-army-vote-concessions.ashx#axzz1ZYYSPfn1 On 11 November 2011, an administrative court in Mansoura ruled that former NDP members were not allowed to stand in the election as independent candidates. It was not immediately known whether this ruling would eventually apply to the whole country.{{cite news| url=http://online.wsj.com/article/SB10001424052970203537304577032302540211524.html?mod=googlenews_wsj | work=The Wall Street Journal | first=Matt | last=Bradley | title=Court in Egypt Bars Ousted Officials From Polls | date=12 November 2011}} On 14 November 2011, the [[Higher Administrative Court]] in Cairo overruled the decision and allowed the former NDP members to stand.{{cite news| url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-15727106 | work=BBC News | title=Egypt lifts election ban on Mubarak-era party members | date=14 November 2011}} [[File:2011-2012 Elections Governorates Distribution.svg|thumb|Number of seats in the People's Assembly per governorate]] {| class="wikitable sortable" border="1" ! rowspan="2" | Governorate ! colspan="2" style="border-right: 3px solid darkgrey;" | PR

Total ! 46 ! style="border-right: 3px solid darkgrey;"| 332 ! 83 ! style="border-right: 3px solid darkgrey;"| 166 ! 498 |} ==Voting System== [[File:2011-2012 Egyptian election phases.svg|thumb|2011-2012 election stages:
{{legend2|#fff6d5|First: 28â29 Nov, run-off on 5â6 Dec}}
{{legend2|#b7c8b7|Second: 14â15 Dec, run-off on 21â22 Dec}}
{{legend2|#ff8080|Third: 3â4 Jan, run-off on 10â11 Jan}}]] The election to the '''Lower House''' - [[People's Assembly of Egypt|People's Assembly]] will take place on the following dates:http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/22697/Egypt/Politics-/SCAF-finally-reveals-parliamentary-elections-dates.aspx * first stage: 28â29 Novemberhttp://english.ahram.org.eg/News/27635.aspx, run-off on 5â6 December; * second stage: 14â15 December, run-off on 21â22 December; * third stage: 3â4 January, run-off on 10â11 January. There are a total 508 seats: 498 seats are elected, and 10 seats appointed, in this case, by the [[Supreme Council of the Armed Forces|Military Council]]{{cite news| url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/11/28/us-egypt-election-system-idUSTRE7AR0VE20111128 | work=Reuters | title=Q+A: How does Egypt's parliamentary election system work? | date=28 November 2011}}, and usually by the President. Out of those 498 seats, two-thirds, meaning 332, shall be elected from the parties or coalition-lists using the [[proportional representation]]-[[largest remainder method]], in 46 districts. The remaining 166 seats are open to candidates running as individuals, who may or may not be affiliated with political parties, numbering two per each of the 83 districs. Out of these, the new parliament must have half "professionals", while the other half need to be "laborers" or "farmers". If the winner of one of the two seats is allocated to a "professional", the second seat in the district shall be handed to a "laborer" or a "farmer". Run-offs are assigned to the individual candidates who did not receive over 50% of the votes in the first round. Additional requirements for parties include listing at least one woman and adopting a specific visual symbol, as an alternative detection to help the illiterate voters.. The same voting procedures shall apply to the upper house's election, too The [[Egyptian Shura Council election, 2012|election for the upper house]], the Shura Council ("the Consultative Council") are to follow on 29 January 2012,http://www.menafn.com/qn_news_story_s.asp?StoryId=1093442368 and will take place in 3 stages as well between between 29 January and 11 March. Out of a total 270 seats: 180 seats are up for grabs and 90 seats shall be appointed after the presidential election, by the president-elect.{{cite news| url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/11/28/us-egypt-election-system-idUSTRE7AR0VE20111128 | work=Reuters | title=Q+A: How does Egypt's parliamentary election system work? | date=28 November 2011}} Following these elections, the parliament shall select a committee that will draft a new constitution for Egypt. The new constitution shall than be submitted to a referendum. Only then will presidential election be held, "no later than 30 June 2012" according to [[Mohamed Hussein Tantawi|Hussein Tantawi]]'s statement. ==Parties== The [[Muslim Brotherhood]] announced on 15 February it would form the [[Freedom and Justice Party (Egypt)|Freedom and Justice Party]] to run in the election.{{cite web|url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4028941,00.html |title=Egypt: Muslim Brotherhood plans political party - Israel News, Ynetnews |publisher=Ynetnews.com |date=20 June 1995 |accessdate=7 September 2011}} The [[Al-Wasat Party]], a moderate Islamic faction of the Muslim Brotherhood, was officially approved as a party on 19 February, fifteen years after its foundation. The Freedom and Justice Party and the liberal [[New Wafd Party]] announced on 13 June 2011 that they would contest the election in an alliance.{{cite news|url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/world/egypts-muslim-brotherhood-forms-coalition-with-liberal-party/2011/06/13/AGQI7OTH_story.html |title=Egyptâs Muslim Brotherhood forms coalition |publisher=The Washington Post |date=22 February 2011 |accessdate=7 September 2011 |first=Leila |last=Fadel}} As a reaction to this centre-right alliance, the different liberal democratic and centrist parties intensified cooperation. Five parties have drafted a joint statement criticising the current electoral law and proposing a new one.{{Citation |url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/~/NewsContent/1/64/14212/Egypt/Politics-/Democratic-Egyptian-political-parties-to-issue-a-j.aspx |title=Democratic Egyptian political parties to issue a joint statement on new electoral law |newspaper= [[Al-Ahram]] Online |date=13 June 2011 |accessdate=28 June 2011}} On 16 August, 15 political and social movements announced an electoral alliance, the [[Egyptian Bloc]]. It consists of liberal, secularist, and centre-left political parties, as well as social organisations and labour unions, and also the traditional Islamic Sufi Liberation Party. Its main objective is to prevent an imminent electoral victory of the Muslim Brotherhood, respectively Freedom and Justice Party. The Wafd Party announced to abandon its alliance with the Islamists over discrepancies concerning the prospective constitution, and to join the new liberal coalition instead.{{Citation |first=Yasmine |last=Saleh |title=Egypt liberals launch âThe Egyptian Blocâ to counter Islamists in Nov vote |newspaper=Al Arabiya News |date=16 August 2011 |url=http://www.alarabiya.net/articles/2011/08/16/162562.html |accessdate=4 September 2011}} On 12 August, three Islamic [[Salafi]] parties (registered [[Al Nour Party|Nour]], and yet unregistered Fadila and Asala parties) announced to run a united candidate list.{{Citation |url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/485598 |first=Hany |last=ElWaziry |title=Salafi political parties to run united in parliamentary elections |newspaper=Al-Masry Al-Youm |date=12 August 2011 |accessdate=12 August 2011}} Five socialist parties and movements formed the [[Coalition of Socialist Forces]] party alliance to contest the elections jointly. Some analysts voiced concerns that former members of the ruling NDP might gain a lot of influence in the newly elected parliament. Among the parties identified to have a strong base in former NDP members were:http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContentP/1/21542/Egypt/Return-of-the-NDP-Mubarakregime-diehards-retrench-.aspx[http://egyptelections.carnegieendowment.org/2011/09/22/national-democratic-party National Democratic Party], Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, carnegieendowment.org. Retrieved on 24 November 2011. * the [[Egyptian Citizen Party]], led by former NDP secretary-general [[Mohamed Ragab]] (other former NDP members include [[Hamdi El-Sayed]], [[Abdel Ahad Gamal El Din]] and [[Nabil Louka Bibawi]]); * [[Renaissance Egypt]] (''[[Misr El-Nahda]]'')/[[Unity Party (Egypt)|Unity Party]] (''[[Al-Etihad (political party)|Al-Etihad]]''), led by former NDP secretary-general [[Hossam Badrawi]]; the party was officially registered under the second name on 20 September 2011;http://english.ahram.org.eg/~/NewsContent/1/64/21886/Egypt/Politics-/First-political-party-run-by-exregime-figure-recei.aspx * the [[Freedom Party (Egypt)|Freedom Party]] (''[[Horreya]]''), led by [[Mamdouh Ali Hassan]], son of [[Mohamed Mahmoud]] (a large number of former NDP MPs joined this party); * the [[Nationalist Egypt Party]], led by [[Anwar Sadat]]'s nephew [[Talaat Sadat]], the last chairman of the NDP ==Monitors== The [[Supreme Council of the Armed Forces]] [[Timeline of the 2011 Egyptian revolution under Supreme Council of the Armed Forces|announced]] that it would bar foreign monitors because of what it claimed was the preservation of Egyptian sovereignty.{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/07/2011720222415556480.html |title=Egypt not to allow foreign poll monitors - Middle East |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date=21 July 2011 |accessdate=7 September 2011}} However, it would welcome foreign "Observers".{{cite web|url=http://www.businessweek.com/news/2011-11-28/egypt-election-2011-facts-and-figures-for-parliamentary-vote.html|title=Egypt allow foreign poll monitors - Middle East |publisher=Business Week |date=28 November 2011 |accessdate=28 November 2011}} Groups such as NDI, The Carter Center, the International Republican Institute and South African, Turkish, Polish and Danish groups have taken part. Alongside 300 foreign civil society representatives there are 25,000 accredited monitors and a lot more concerned citizens who have pledged to alert the organizers regarding any abuses they encounter.{{cite web|url=http://www.jpost.com/MiddleEast/Article.aspx?id=247317|title=Egypt poll monitors - Middle East |publisher=Jeruslaem Post|date=28 November 2011 |accessdate=28 November 2011}} Additionally, many egyptians have turned to citizen monitoring through social media such as [[Facebook]], [[Twitter]] and [[YouTube]], uploading cited violations or turnouts. ==Poll Surveys== A 9â20 March poll survey amongst 615 voting age Egyptians by the [[International Peace Institute]] (IPI) showed that [[New Wafd Party]], the oldest liberal party, had the support of 23 percent, 12 percent of Egyptian voters would vote for the [[Freedom and Justice Party]], and 10 percent still supported the now dissolved [[National Democratic Party]].{{cite web|author=Ø¹Ø§Ø¯Ù Ø§ÙØ¯Ø±Ø¬ÙÙ ÙÙØ§ÙÙ |url=http://www.ipinst.org/images/pdfs/egypt-poll-results-april2011.pdf |title=EGYPT NATIONAL SURVEY |publisher=International Peace Institute Poll |date=20 March 2011 |accessdate=7 September 2011}} A [[The Gallup Organization|Gallup]] poll from June 2011 showed that the [[Muslim Brotherhood]] had the support of 15 percent of the survey group, with over 60% of the people undecided.{{cite web|url=http://patdollard.com/2011/06/gallup-15-of-egyptians-support-muslim-brotherhood-69-want-religious-leaders-to-have-advisory-role/ |title=Gallup: 15% Of Egyptians Support Muslim Brotherhood, 69% Want Religious Leaders To Have "Advisory Role" at Pat Dollard |publisher=Patdollard.com |date= |accessdate=7 September 2011}} The dissolved [[National Democratic Party]] would have scored 10 percent, the liberal [[New Wafd Party]] 9 percent, and the newly launched [[Wasat Party]] 5 percent.{{Citation needed|date=August 2011}} July 7 public opinion survey by [[Al Jazeera]] showed following voting intentions: 46% of those polled indicated they would vote for the Muslim Brotherhood, running under the Freedom and Justice Party banner, in the November parliamentary elections. An additional 27% would support the Salafist-backed Nour Party. The Wasat party, which represents a moderate islamism, came in third with 6%. The youth-based Hizb ElAdl, or Justice Party, was the top ranking secularist group, with only 5%.{{cite web|url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2011/aug/1/shut-up-egypt-is-muslim/ |title=EDITORIAL: Shut up, Egypt is Muslim |publisher=Washington Times |date=1 August 2011 |accessdate=7 September 2011}} July 26 survey by [[Newsweek]]/[[The Daily Beast]] showed following results: 29% Not sure/Undecided, 17% Freedom and Justice Party, 11% Al-Wafd Party, 7% National Democratic Party, 7% [[Free Egyptians Party]], 5% Justice Party, 4% [[Freedom Egypt Party]], 3% [[Egyptian Current Party]], 3% [[Dignity Party (Egypt)|Dignity Party]], 2% [[Socialist Labour Party (Egypt)|Egyptian Labor Party]], 2% [[El-Ghad Party]], 2% [[National Progressive Unionist Party|Tagammu Party]], 1% AlWasat Party, 1% [[Democratic Front Party]], 7% Other.{{cite web|url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2011/07/26/egypt-political-poll-muslim-brotherhood-influence-troubles-for-west.html |title=Egypt Political Poll: Muslim Brotherhood Influence, Troubles For West |publisher=The Daily Beast |date=26 July 2011 |accessdate=7 September 2011}} An August 2011 survey by the Al-Ahram Centre for Political and Strategic Studies (ACPSS) and Danish-Egyptian Dialogue Institute (DEDI) showed the following results: Egypt can expect a large turnout of voters in the upcoming parliamentary elections â more than 80% say that they are likely to vote, only 17.7% would not go to the polls. More than half of the voters (57.1%) are still undecided. The Muslim Brotherhoodâs âFreedom and Justice Partyâ has support from 31.5% of the decided voters. However, the âFreedom and Justice Partyâ splits the electorate in half â 39% of the voters view the party unfavourably vs. 36% in the favourable group. The political parties in general suffer from a lack of trust from the electorate â only the [[Coalition of the Youth of the Revolution|Revolutionary Youth Coalition]] has a strong favourable/unfavourable (44% vs. 24%) standing. The party has a double digit support of 17.2%. The Wafd Party received 14.8%, Free Egyptians 7.5%, Nour 6.0%, [[Egyptian Social Democratic Party]] 5.2%, [[Arab Democratic Nasserist Party|Nasserites]] 3.7%, Justice Party 2.6%, Tagammu 2.2%. Eleven other parties were also taken into account by the surveyors.{{cite web|author=23 August 2011 by DIPDPhoto: UN Alliance of Civilizations |url=http://dipd.dk/2011/08/egypt-survey-favourable-to-amr-moussa/ |title=Survey favourable to Amr Moussa | DIPD |publisher=Dipd.dk |date=23 August 2011 |accessdate=7 September 2011}}{{cite journal|url=http://dipd.dk/wp-content/uploads/2011/08/Egypt-Survey-1 August-2011.pdf |title=National Voter Survey in Egypt |publisher=Al-Ahram Centre for Political and Strategic Studies (ACPSS) |date=22 August 2011 |accessdate=7 September 2011}} The second national voter survey by APSSC and DEDI indicated that 39% of voters have already decided they would choose the Freedom and Justice Party (FJP) in the upcoming parliamentary elections, while 20% voted in favour of the Wafd Party and 6.8% chose the Salafist Nour Party. According to the poll, 55% of those surveyed remain undecided.{{cite web|last=Danish-Egyptian Dialogue Institute (DEDI)|title=2nd National Voter Survey in Egypt|url=http://dedi.org.eg/wp-content/uploads/Voter-poll-survey.pdf|publisher=dedi.org.eg|accessdate=13 Oct 2011}} The third APSSC/DEDI surveys, in November, indicates that 49% of voters had already decided to whom to vote, 35.7% of which chose the [[Freedom and Justice Party (Egypt)|FJP]], versus 26.2% that choose the [[New Wafd Party|Wafd]].{{cite web|last=Danish-Egyptian Dialogue Institute (DEDI)|title=3rd National Voter Survey in Egypt|url=http://dedi.org.eg/wp-content/uploads/3rd-Poll-Press-Release.pdf|publisher=dedi.org.eg|accessdate=12 November 2011}} {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" |- ! rowspan=2 | Conducted/

DEDI || 2,400 || 35.7% || 26.2% || 8.9% || 3.9% || 5.2% || 2.1% || 2.0% || 0.4% || 5.2% || 10.9% || 51% | colspan="12" style="text-align:center;"| |} ==Voter turnout== About 50 million people are eligible to vote out of a population in excess of 85 million - with candidates from 50 registered political parties. Large crowds turned out at the polling stations for the first stage of the polls. Such a turnout had caused the election committee to extend the hours of polling by two hours to end at 9:00 PM.{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-15914277|title=Egypt voter Turnouts - Middle East |publisher=BBC |date=28 November 2011 |accessdate=28 November 2011}} Even a majority of the protesters in Tahrir square who have been at the sit-in after deadly clashes a week earlier, had left their sit-in to join the polls before returning back to Tahrir Square. Although some have also boycotted the elections. Although the government gave no official figures, the Muslim Brotherhood's observers estimated a turnout of about 30 to 32 percent, for the first day, in the 9 governorates that voted in the first phase, while in Cairo, turnout was reported at about 27 percent. An "exceptionally high turnout" was also reported in the [[Asyut Governorate|governorate of Asyut]], especially among women.{{cite news |title=Millions vote in landmark Egypt elections |author=[[Al-Jazeera English]] |url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2011/11/2011112951358487462.html |newspaper= |date=27 November 2011 |accessdate=27 November 2011}} On the second day of the first round independent monitors placed the turnout at over 50 percent, while a spokesman for the military said that it could exceed 70 percent, maybe even reaching 80 percent. Abroad, turnout was around 60-70 percent according to the Egyptian foreign minister.{{cite news |title=Egyptian elections mark break with the past |author=[[Al-Jazeera English]] |url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2011/11/2011112919319900697.html |newspaper= |date=30 November 2011 |accessdate=30 November 2011}} ==Results== In the first phase of elections to the lower house (28 November), out of the resulits of the 62% of eligible voters who attended ("the highest number since the days of Pharaoh," according to election commission head, Abdul Ibrahim[http://www.nrg.co.il/online/1/ART2/312/417.html]), Many Individual candidates did not receive over 50% threshold, and therefore are expected to face a run-off on December 5. Official results for each party or coalition-lists has not yet been released, but it is thought, by various international channels as well as leaks from people involved in the count, that the Freedom and Justice Party, lead by the [[Muslim Brotherhood]], is expected to receive around 40% of the vote, and the [[Salafi]]s between 15-30 percent, and if this is an indication of the next rounds of elections, then Islamist parties will have a 60% Parliamentary majority. However, it is unclear how much power will be concentrated in the hands of Parliament, as the military council still controls the country.[http://www.nrg.co.il/online/1/ART2/312/417.html]. On this same issue and also in regard to the future Constitution, the military has clarified, According to sources, that "the council will not act to cancel the elections and will accept all results as the will of the people. The council will, however, insist on two red lines. It will demand that the military's status remain unchanged and also that the secular nature of Egypt and the human rights of the Egyptian people be protected" [http://www.haaretz.com/news/middle-east/egypt-s-ruling-military-council-deeply-concerned-by-islamist-election-victory-1.399314]. ===Actual results released=== *On December 4, actual results from the '''first phase''' elections to the '''Lower House''' were first released: {{electiontable|Egyptian parliamentary election, 2011â2012}} |- style="background-color:#E9E9E9" |- style="background-color:#E9E9E9" !
